In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can define a function to wrap strings as follows:

```julia
function wrap_string(str::AbstractString; text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = []
    for word in split(str)
        if length(word) + sum(length.(lines)) > text_width
            push!(lines, "")
        end
        push!(lines, word)
    end
    return join(lines)
end
```

This function works by splitting the input string into words and then iterating over them. For each word, it checks if the current length of the line (the sum of the lengths of all previous words plus the current word) exceeds the specified `text_width`. If so, it adds an empty string to the list of lines to force a new line. Finally, it joins the lines back into a single string and returns it.

You can use this function as follows:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! How are you today? This is a very long sentence that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line.")
"Hello there!\nHow are you today?\nThis is a very long sentence that should be wrapped at 10 characters per line."
```

In this example, the string is wrapped at 10 characters per line as specified by the `text_width` parameter.
